item.title: With a woman in prison for a stillbirth, California's murder law is tested
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Adora Perez was imprisoned for delivering a stillborn baby after using drugs. Her case largely went unnoticed until another woman was charged.
item.content:encoded: Adora Perez was imprisoned for delivering a stillborn baby after using drugs. Her case largely went unnoticed until another woman was charged.

media:content.media:description: HANFORD, CA - NOVEMBER 16, 2020 - Tina Perez holds a photo of her daughter Adora Perez in Hanford, California on November 16, 2020. Adora has been in prison for nearly three years after she gave birth to a stillborn baby and prosecutors charged her with murder, alleging her meth use was to blame. Perez took a deal in which she pleaded no contest to involuntary manslaughter and was sentenced to 11 years because she thought it was the only way to avoid a potential life sentence. The ACLU has launched a new push to free her, saying ineffective legal counsel led to the verdict because her lawyer overlooked serious flaws in her case and never told her that her conduct might not be a crime in California. That's despite the fact Perez paid the woman $15,000 to represent her, according to her family. A pro bono lawyer retained by the ACLU has now filed a legal motion seeking to have an appeal of her case reopened. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: During the pandemic, chaplains are a lifeline for inmates
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: At a time of greater isolation, chaplains at L.A. County jails and state prisons say there's a greater need for their work.
item.content:encoded: At a time of greater isolation, chaplains at L.A. County jails and state prisons say there's a greater need for their work.

media:content.media:description: SAN GABRIEL, CA - DECEMBER 03, 2020 - Brother Dennis Gibbs corresponds with inmates at the Community of Divine Love, an Episcopal monastery in San Gabriel on December 3, 2020. Brother Dennis writes inmates letters in longhand that he visited before the pandemic struck. "It's truly a labor of love," said Brother Dennis about writing the letters. At a time when public visits to jails and prisons have been suspended, some chaplains have felt an extra sense of responsibility to stay connected to the inmates. Brother Dennis Gibbs and Sister Greta Ronningen have decided not to go into correctional settings for safety reasons, but they've developed a steady correspondence with inmates and try to give them hope and support at a time when they are living in more isolation than usual. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: With ICUs hitting capacity, hospitals turn to desperate measures
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money
item.description: Hospitalizations are continuing to rise at unprecedented levels, and officials have limited options for boosting capacity. Among the tools: Canceling scheduled surgeries; keeping critically ill patients in emergency rooms; training nurses from elsewhere in hospitals to help with intensive care; and increasing the numbers of patients an ICU nurse can treat.
item.content:encoded: Hospitalizations are continuing to rise at unprecedented levels, and officials have limited options for boosting capacity. Among the tools: Canceling scheduled surgeries; keeping critically ill patients in emergency rooms; training nurses from elsewhere in hospitals to help with intensive care; and increasing the numbers of patients an ICU nurse can treat.

media:content.media:description: LOMA LINDA, CA - DECEMBER 15, 2020: Pulmonologist Dr. Laren Tan, right, with his medical team of nurses and respiratory therapists look in on a COVID-19 patient before she is intubated in the ICU at Loma Linda University Medical Center on December 15, 2020 in Loma Linda, California. The hospital is experiencing a huge surge in COVID-19 patients. Dr. Michael Matus, chief of hospitalist said they are currently admitting more than 15 patients a day. The hospital has added 5 additional Covid units in addition to ICU. Many of the ICU patients have underlying health issues. Once those patients get Covid, "It's a marathon that they can't run, said Dr. Tan.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Is it worth it?' How distance learning brings new challenges to college applications
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: Amid virtual learning, replicating the college counseling process online has been difficult, with some students opting out. Others continue to be resilient despite challenges.
item.content:encoded: Amid virtual learning, replicating the college counseling process online has been difficult, with some students opting out. Others continue to be resilient despite challenges.

media:content.media:description: WOODLAND HILLS, CA - DECEMBER 09, 2020: Cynthia Medrano, a college counselor at Alliance Marine Tech High School, an LAUSD charter school in Sun Valley, works remotely at her home in Woodland Hills. Medrano is a dedicated counselor who has worked hard this semester to connect with her students remotely, texting, emailing, and setting up one-on-one virtual meetings to encourage them to apply to college and make sure they've completed the necessary steps, despite the absence of an on-campus presence. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: In love and in limbo, a Texas rancher was separated from her husband by immigration policy
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: With COVID and Trump's immigration policies, it took 18 months for this Texas rancher to bring her Brazilian husband to the U.S. Biden could move to ease restrictions.
item.content:encoded: With COVID and Trump's immigration policies, it took 18 months for this Texas rancher to bring her Brazilian husband to the U.S. Biden could move to ease restrictions.

media:content.media:description: Kathleen Morriss, right, Falko Konig, walk through Praca da Republica, Nova Petropolis, Brazil, September 9, 2020. Morriss, is a fifth generation Texan rancher, is trying to get her Brazilian husband, Falko Konig, to the U.S. However, Trump's immigration policies and COVID-19 has slowed down and pretty much halted an already glacially slow process. Trump has bogged down the process because he's moved much of the immigration personnel usually dedicated to spousal visas to focus on fraud. That's really slowed down the process. It used to be 9 to 12 months to get a spousal visa. After Trump, it's more like 12 to 15 months to get the same visa. In addition, COVID has shuttered many U.S. embassies, including the one in Brazil.

item.title: Fairgrounds, theme parks open drive-through holiday shows to offset lost revenue
item.dc:creator: Hugo Martín
item.description: The pandemic means trouble for huge venues that thrive on crowds. So they're trying holiday drive-throughs instead of traditional Christmas events, live parties and Santa visits.
item.content:encoded: The pandemic means trouble for huge venues that thrive on crowds. So they're trying holiday drive-throughs instead of traditional Christmas events, live parties and Santa visits.

media:content.media:description: VALENCIA, CA - DECEMBER 03: A young visitor looks out at the falling snow and colorful lights at Six Flags Magic Mountain. The holiday drive-through event is to help make up for the revenue lost by the closure of the theme park. The drive-through is open daily until January 3, 2021, unless health department orders force them to close. Similar events are happening at fairgrounds and race tracks. Photographed at Six Flags Magic Mountain on Thursday, Dec. 3, 2020 in Valencia, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Million-dollar views, cheap rent and allegations of favoritism at California state parks
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: Current and former California parks employees allege state property is being used to benefit favored staff members, according to a Times investigation.
item.content:encoded: Current and former California parks employees allege state property is being used to benefit favored staff members, according to a Times investigation.

media:content.media:description: NEWPORT BEACH, CALIF. -- FRIDAY, DECEMBER 13, 2019: A view of Crystal Cove cottages #21, shown in middle and #17, two cottages down, which are designated for rent by California State Parks employees at Crystal Cove State Beach in Newport Beach, Calif., on Dec. 13, 2019. California government workers get cheap rent for state property, taxpayers foot the maintenance. Parks employees continue to rent two Crystal Cove cottages. Cottage 17 is steps from the beach, an 1,100 square foot home featuring French windows and wood siding. It was restored in 2006 as employee housing and rents for $232 a month. A second cottage, #21, is rented to a park employee for $395 a month. Similar cottages are available to the public for $261 a night, and those are booked as much as seven months in advance. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A lawsuit alleges 'unchecked groping' and other sex abuse at O.C. homeless shelters
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: The American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California filed a lawsuit Thursday alleging that sex abuse, overcrowding and unhealthy conditions are rampant in three Orange County homeless shelters, saying conditions had not improved after a scathing 2019 report on the shelters.
item.content:encoded: The American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California filed a lawsuit Thursday alleging that sex abuse, overcrowding and unhealthy conditions are rampant in three Orange County homeless shelters, saying conditions had not improved after a scathing 2019 report on the shelters.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CALIF. -- WEDNESDAY, MARCH 13, 2019: ***Report embargoed until Thursday, March 14, at 9 a.m.*** A view of the exterior of The Courtyard Transitional Center in Santa Ana, Calif., on March 13, 2019. The Los Angeles Times was denied access to take photos inside the facility. The ACLU is releasing an investigation into conditions at three temporary homeless shelters in Orange County: The Courtyard Transitional Center in Santa Ana; Bridges at Kraemer Place in Anaheim; and SAFEPlace in Santa Ana. The Courtyard Transitional Center has some of the worst allegations against it, including unsanitary conditions and physical, verbal and sexual abuse. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times
